Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
I stood on the edge of the crowded street, the air thick with chants and the sharp scent of city concrete. My stepfather’s voice buzzed in my ear through the phone, trembling as he confessed how lost he felt since losing his job. He needed me—he said I was the only one he could talk to, the only one who understood. I pressed the phone tighter, trying to sound steady, offering words of comfort while my heart pounded with worry for him.

Suddenly, the crowd surged forward. A friend grabbed my arm, eyes wide with urgency. “Come on! We have to cross—this is our chance to make a statement!” The barricade loomed ahead, police watching, the line between protest and trespass clear. I hesitated, torn. As a citizen, I knew the law, the importance of respecting boundaries and public order. But my friend’s grip tightened, and the crowd’s energy pulled at me.

My stepfather’s voice cracked through the phone, desperate for reassurance. My friend tugged harder, demanding action. I felt split in two—one part needed to be the steady support my family relied on, the other pressured to stand up and act as a member of my community. My heart raced, caught between the voices on either side, unsure which role I could bear to let down.
